title: The phases of QCD reached in terrestrial and cosmic colliders
summary: We review the current state of knowledge of the phase diagram of QCD through lattice, effective field theories, and chiral models. Several sections through the three dimensional phase diagram are known for $N_f=2+1$ with good precision. Due to technical advances in lattice techniques over the last decade or so, new aspects of the phase diagram can now be explored. We review current lattice results. The newly acquired knowledge can be used to reconstruct the full phase diagram for physical QCD, \ie, $N_f=1+1+1$. We remark on the computations which would help understand this better, and what the current constraints are on matter in neutron star cores. We also remark on the physics of the chiral transition and neutron stars in the 't Hooft large $N_c$ limit.

AI.tldr: This paper reviews the current understanding of the QCD phase diagram through various theoretical approaches and recent lattice results, with a focus on reconstructing the full phase diagram for physical QCD and implications for neutron star cores.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to synthesize the latest advancements in lattice techniques and their application to exploring new aspects of the QCD phase diagram, particularly for physical QCD (N_f=1+1+1), and to understand the implications for the matter in neutron star cores.
AI.method: The method involves reviewing existing literature on the QCD phase diagram obtained from lattice calculations, effective field theories, and chiral models, and using this information to infer the characteristics of the full phase diagram for physical QCD.
AI.result: The result is an updated view of the QCD phase diagram, including precise sections for N_f=2+1, and insights into the reconstruction of the phase diagram for physical QCD. It also discusses the constraints and computational needs for a better understanding of matter in neutron star cores.
AI.conclusion: The conclusion highlights the progress made in understanding the QCD phase diagram due to recent technical advances in lattice methods, and it points out the remaining challenges and future directions for research, especially regarding the physics of the chiral transition and neutron stars in the large N_c limit.

title: The Fredenhagen-Marcu operator in the gauge-Higgs Z(2) LGT at finite temperature
summary: We explore the possibility to use the Fredenhagen-Marcu operator as an order parameter of the deconfinement phase transition in gauge-matter systems at finite temperature. Concretely, we compute by numerical simulations this operator in the (2+1)-dimensional Z(2) lattice gauge theory (LGT) with Z(2) gauge fields coupled to Z(2)-valued Higgs fields. Our conclusion is that the Fredenhagen-Marcu operator can indeed serve as an order parameter capable of distinguishing the deconfinement phase from the Higgs and confinement phases of the theory.

AI.tldr: The Fredenhagen-Marcu operator is evaluated as a potential order parameter for the deconfinement phase transition in (2+1)-dimensional Z(2) lattice gauge theory with Higgs fields, and it successfully distinguishes between the deconfinement, Higgs, and confinement phases.
AI.motivation: To investigate if the Fredenhagen-Marcu operator can be used as an order parameter to identify the deconfinement phase transition in gauge-matter systems at finite temperature, specifically within the context of (2+1)-dimensional Z(2) lattice gauge theory coupled with Z(2)-valued Higgs fields.
AI.method: Numerical simulations are performed to compute the Fredenhagen-Marcu operator in the (2+1)-dimensional Z(2) lattice gauge theory that includes both Z(2) gauge fields and Z(2)-valued Higgs fields.
AI.result: The Fredenhagen-Marcu operator is found to effectively serve as an order parameter, distinguishing the deconfinement phase from the Higgs and confinement phases of the theory.
AI.conclusion: The study concludes that the Fredenhagen-Marcu operator can indeed be used as an effective order parameter for identifying the deconfinement phase transition in the specified gauge-matter system.
